categories: Finnish terms derived from Germanic languages

words.etymology_text: From a short form of ancient personal names containing the element ikä (“age”), such as Ikävalko or Ikäheimo, possibly also from some Germanic name + + -nen.
A pre-Christian given name, probably ikä + heimo.
A pre-Christian given name, probably ikä + valko, latter from the surname Valkonen.

glosses: Used other than figuratively or idiomatically: see ikeen, alla.

words.etymology_text: From ikeen (“of yoke”) + alla (“under”). Ultimately a calque of Latin sub iugum (whence also English under the yoke).

glosses: third-person possessive form of comitative plural of ikä

examples.english: I could never ever kiss her. / Never in this world could I kiss her.

raw_glosses: (chiefly in the negative) never ever, never in this world, never in a million years (strong rejection)
glosses: never ever, never in this world, never in a million years (strong rejection)

words.etymology_text: Contraction of ikinä (“ever”) + maailmassa (“in the world”)

examples.text: En ole ikinä nähnyt mitään noin suurta.
examples.english: I have never seen anything that big.

examples.text: Älä ikinä sano mitään tuollaista hänestä!
examples.english: Don’t you ever say anything like that about her/him again!

examples.text: En ole ikinä edes suudellut häntä.
examples.english: I have never ever even kissed her.

examples.text: Oletko ikinä nähnyt mitään noin suurta?

words.etymology_text: A variant of earlier and now dialectal akkuna (see it for more). The initial vowel, also found in Ingrian ikkuna, Karelian ikkuna, Ludian ikkun and Veps ikun, may be due to influence from Russian икона (ikona) (possibly even earlier Old East Slavic икона (ikona, “icon”)). Sense 3 is semantic loan from English window.
From the taxonomic name of the species, Herpestes ichneumon.
